facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 23, 1963, of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 24 of 1963.
Election held in February 1962 for reserved seat in Berasia Constituency, district of Sehore, Madhya Pradesh.
Appellant Bhaiyalal, respondent No. 1 Harikishan Singh, and three others were candidates.
Appellant declared duly elected on 26th February 1962, having polled highest votes; respondent No. 1 was next rival.
Respondent No. 1 filed election petition challenging validity of appellant's election on ground that appellant belonged to Dohar caste, not Chamar scheduled caste.

Appellant filed nomination paper on 19th January 1962 before Returning Officer at Sehore, declaring himself member of Chamar scheduled caste of Madhya Pradesh in relation to Sehore district; declaration accepted by Returning Officer.
Respondent No. 1 contended Dohar caste not recognised as scheduled caste for Sehore and Raisen districts; Returning Officer improperly accepted declaration.
Appellant contended election petition not maintainable as respondent No. 1 did not deposit security of Rs. 2,000 as prescribed.
Election Tribunal framed issues: first four on validity of nomination as Chamar; fifth on competence of petition.
Both parties led oral and documentary evidence; Tribunal found for respondent No. 1 on caste issue and against appellant on security deposit; allowed petition, declared election invalid.
Appellant appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court; High Court confirmed Tribunal's findings on both points, dismissed appeal on 23rd April 1963.
Appellant's case: Dohar Chamar is sub-caste of Chamar scheduled caste, also called Mochi.
Respondent No. 1 examined 13 witnesses from appellant's caste asserting Dohar different from Chamar; no intercaste marriage or dining; lived in different mohallas.

Kishanlal (P.W. 4), Secretary of Dohar Samaj started by appellant (appellant was Sarpanch), stated Dohar and Chamar entirely different; no inter-dining/marriage; Dohars not Mochis; Chamars do leather work.
Respondent produced documents Exts. P.2 to P.5 (1956, signed by appellant describing himself as Dohar, not Chamar); other documents P.8, P.10 etc. similar.
Appellant examined himself and witnesses claiming Dohar same as Mochi, sub-caste of Chamar; produced 22 documents, some accepted by High Court but insufficient to prove sub-caste.
Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 specifies Chamar, Jatav or Mochi for relevant area.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant belonged to Chamar scheduled caste entitling him to contest reserved seat.
Whether election petition maintainable due to security deposit.
Whether plea that Dohar is sub-caste of Chamar permissible under Article 341.
Whether President can specify Scheduled Castes by reference to districts or sub-areas.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant is Dohar Chamar, sub-caste of Chamar scheduled caste, also called Mochi.
Election petition not maintainable, no security deposit of Rs. 2000.
President cannot specify lists of Scheduled Castes by reference to districts/sub-areas; must be for entire State.

respondent_arguments.text: Dohar caste distinct from Chamar; not recognised as scheduled caste for Sehore/Raisen; no intercaste relations.
Security deposit made in accordance with statutory requirements.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent findings of fact by Tribunal and High Court on caste against appellant; no reason to interfere.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both courts considered oral and documentary evidence; respondent's evidence including Kishanlal (P.W.4) and documents compelling.

court_reasoning.text: Plea that Dohar is sub-caste of Chamar not permissible under Article 341; must look only to Presidential notification listing Chamar, Jatav or Mochi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No modification by evidence; normal rule against showing sub-castes included.

court_reasoning.text: Election petition valid; security deposit compliant.
President authorised under Article 341(1) to specify by districts/areas based on backwardness varying regionally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object to provide protection considering local backwardness.

holdings.text: Appellant does not belong to Chamar caste; not qualified for reserved seat.
Sub-caste plea not entertainable under Article 341; determination by Presidential Order only.
President can specify Scheduled Castes by reference to areas/districts.

precedents_cited.relevance: Similar question on whether enquiry into caste equivalence permissible; normal rule against modification by evidence of sub-castes.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines Scheduled Castes via Presidential Order; no variation except by Parliament; allows specification by parts/groups/areas.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950
sections: Entry specifying Chamar, Jatav or Mochi for relevant districts
statutes_cited.relevance: Determines scheduled castes for Sehore; Dohar not included.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, confirming High Court and Tribunal; held appellant not belonging to Chamar scheduled caste, election invalid.
outcome.relief_granted: Election petition allowed; appellant's election declared invalid.

key_quotes.text: in order to determine whether or not a particular caste is a scheduled caste within the meaning of Art. 341, one has to look at the public notification issued by the President in that behalf.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of Article 341.

key_quotes.text: it may be accepted that it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show... that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is also a part of caste A.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects sub-caste plea based on precedent.

key_quotes.text: the Dohar and the Chamar castes are entirely different. The Chamars... take off skins from dead animals, prepare shoes and do leather work the Dohar... is not the sub-caste of Chamar caste.
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Key witness evidence relied upon by court.
